repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
Selecting and deleting all lines in a file with multiple diagnostics leads to the following error:
```
Error in CursorMoved Autocommands for "<buffer=9>":
Lua callback: ...nvimdcgMep/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua:1587: Invalid 'line': out of range
stack traceback:
        [C]: in function 'nvim_buf_set_extmark'
        ...nvimdcgMep/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua:1587: in function 'render_virtual_text'
        ...nvimdcgMep/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua:1645: in function <...nvimdcgMep/usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua:1644>
```
This seems to have been introduced along with the changes made in the following PR [#33517](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/33517)

How to Reproduce:
 - Use a minimal lsp diagnostic config:   ` vim.diagnostic.config({virtual_lines  = {current_line = true}, virtual_text = {current_line = false}})`
- Create a test file named test.lua
- Ensure you have a lua lsp active 
- Write 3-4 lines of errors (I used the following): 
```
asd
asd
asd
asd
```
- Select and delete all lines in the file (for example using the vim motion VggD from the bottom of the file)

Solution:
This PR introduces a check to verify that the line number does not exceed the number of lines within the buffer. This allows the CursorMoved auto-command to run as intended.

Fixes https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34081

comment_data.body: I think that instead of skipping the diagnostic here we should clamp the line as `vim.diagnostic.get` does. That would make the API behavior more consistent (as suggested by https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/34013).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1594,12 +1594,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
 --- @param opts vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText
 local function render_virtual_text(namespace, bufnr, diagnostics, opts)
   local lnum = api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[1] - 1
+  local bufferlength = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
   api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(bufnr, namespace, 0, -1)
 
   for line, line_diagnostics in pairs(diagnostics) do
     local virt_texts = M._get_virt_text_chunks(line_diagnostics, opts)
     local skip = (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
       or (opts.current_line == false and line == lnum)
+      or (opts.current_line == false and line >= bufferlength)

comment_data.body:
Ideally clamping diagnostic values makes absolute sense. But from my understanding (and please correct me if I'm wrong), the current implementation makes use of a "CursorMoved" autocommand when displaying virtual_text (and virtual_lines for the matter). 
The diagnostic table is not currently recomputed within this callback but when diagnostics are updated, and hence on CursorMoved you end up with diagnostic_lines table containing lnums that can potentially exceed the buffer length on deleting lines. We could recompute diagnostic_lines (and clamp to bufferlength) within the callback, however i fear this might be a tad too expensive with having to loop through diagnostics an additional time per cursor movement.
Does this sound right? Wouldn't the curently implemented check be the most efficient way to do this instead?

Sorry if i've misunderstood something. This is my first PR to this repo ^^.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1594,12 +1594,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
 --- @param opts vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText
 local function render_virtual_text(namespace, bufnr, diagnostics, opts)
   local lnum = api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[1] - 1
+  local bufferlength = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
   api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(bufnr, namespace, 0, -1)
 
   for line, line_diagnostics in pairs(diagnostics) do
     local virt_texts = M._get_virt_text_chunks(line_diagnostics, opts)
     local skip = (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
       or (opts.current_line == false and line == lnum)
+      or (opts.current_line == false and line >= bufferlength)

comment_data.body:
> however i fear this might be a tad too expensive with having to loop through diagnostics an additional time per cursor movement.

I don't think that clamping would have any performance impact.

> Wouldn't the curently implemented check be the most efficient way to do this instead?

I'm not smart enough to determine which approach is the most efficient. I was making a suggestion, feel free to pursue your approach instead.

   local lnum = api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[1] - 1
+  local bufferlength = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
   api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(bufnr, namespace, 0, -1)
 
   for line, line_diagnostics in pairs(diagnostics) do
     local virt_texts = M._get_virt_text_chunks(line_diagnostics, opts)
     local skip = (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
       or (opts.current_line == false and line == lnum)
+      or (opts.current_line == false and line >= bufferlength)

comment_data.body: Does this current approach seem more in line with previously existing methods?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1594,12 +1594,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
 --- @param opts vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText
 local function render_virtual_text(namespace, bufnr, diagnostics, opts)
   local lnum = api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[1] - 1
+  local bufferlength = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
   api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(bufnr, namespace, 0, -1)
 
   for line, line_diagnostics in pairs(diagnostics) do
     local virt_texts = M._get_virt_text_chunks(line_diagnostics, opts)
     local skip = (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
       or (opts.current_line == false and line == lnum)
+      or (opts.current_line == false and line >= bufferlength)

comment_data.body:
I think skipping the diagnostic as you had originally is better, that way we don't compute yet another filtered table (CursorMoved is fired a lot).

You don't need to check `opts.current_line == false` though. If `line` is greater than the number of lines in the buffer, the diagnostic should always be skipped.

```lua
local skip = line >= bufferlength or ...
```

We should also check that `skip` is false before we ever compute the virt text chunks, as right now we compute those unconditionally and they just get thrown away.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1594,12 +1594,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
 --- @param opts vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText
 local function render_virtual_text(namespace, bufnr, diagnostics, opts)
   local lnum = api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[1] - 1
+  local bufferlength = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
   api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(bufnr, namespace, 0, -1)
 
   for line, line_diagnostics in pairs(diagnostics) do
     local virt_texts = M._get_virt_text_chunks(line_diagnostics, opts)
     local skip = (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
       or (opts.current_line == false and line == lnum)
+      or (opts.current_line == false and line >= bufferlength)

comment_data.body: Done! Have cleaned up the implementation a bit as well.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1594,12 +1594,14 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
 --- @param opts vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText
 local function render_virtual_text(namespace, bufnr, diagnostics, opts)
   local lnum = api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[1] - 1
+  local bufferlength = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
   api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(bufnr, namespace, 0, -1)
 
   for line, line_diagnostics in pairs(diagnostics) do
     local virt_texts = M._get_virt_text_chunks(line_diagnostics, opts)
     local skip = (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
       or (opts.current_line == false and line == lnum)
+      or (opts.current_line == false and line >= bufferlength)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    if
      (line >= buf_len)
      or (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
      or (opts.current_line == false and line == lnum)
    then
      return false
    end
    
    return true
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1594,21 +1594,33 @@ M.handlers.underline = {
 --- @param opts vim.diagnostic.Opts.VirtualText
 local function render_virtual_text(namespace, bufnr, diagnostics, opts)
   local lnum = api.nvim_win_get_cursor(0)[1] - 1
+  local buf_len = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
   api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(bufnr, namespace, 0, -1)
 
-  for line, line_diagnostics in pairs(diagnostics) do
-    local virt_texts = M._get_virt_text_chunks(line_diagnostics, opts)
-    local skip = (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
+  local function should_render(line)
+    if
+      (line >= buf_len)
+      or (opts.current_line == true and line ~= lnum)
       or (opts.current_line == false and line == lnum)
+    then
+      return false
+    else
+      return true
+    end

comment_regular_data.body:
> Could we add a test?

Had a go at adding tests for this. This behavior seems to stem from the "CursorMoved" auto command, which I cannot seem to trigger from within the diagnostic functional test framework :( Any pointers?

> > Could we add a test?
> 
> Had a go at adding tests for this. This behavior seems to stem from the "CursorMoved" auto command, which I cannot seem to trigger from within the diagnostic functional test framework :( Any pointers?

You can try using `vim.api.nvim_exec_autocmds()`.
@gpanders  Should be good to go if you're happy!

title: fix(diagnostics): fixed virtual_text cursormoved autocmd error
